race.name: Walburg Dirty 30
race.tagline: Thirty miles of pure Texas Hill Country grit - where limestone legends are made

distances.name: 30 Mile
distances.description: Challenging 30 miles through Texas Hill Country

race.terrain: Texas Hill Country gravel - rolling hills, limestone roads, ranch land, technical sections
race.weather: Texas December - mild to cool temperatures (50s-60s°F), generally pleasant racing conditions
uniqueCharacteristics: Classic Texas Hill Country gravel race
30-mile format is perfect for beginners and experienced riders
December timing provides ideal Texas weather

prestige.explanation: As a regional Texas gravel race, Walburg Dirty 30 has local recognition and is becoming a growing institution in the Texas gravel scene, but lacks national significance or series affiliation.

race_quality.explanation: Good organization with proper course marking, aid stations, and a festive finish line atmosphere. Solid regional race production without the polish of elite-tier events.

experience.explanation: An enjoyable day of Texas gravel racing with beautiful Hill Country views, a manageable distance, and a welcoming post-race celebration. Riders leave satisfied but not transformed.

community.explanation: Good Texas gravel community vibe with friendly locals and growing participation. The December timing adds a festive, end-of-season celebration feel.

field_depth.explanation: Primarily draws regional Texas riders with some competition at the front. No elite pro field or series points, though strong local racers show up to compete. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Good value for a well-organized 30-mile gravel race. Registration fees are reasonable for a regional event, and you get a quality Texas Hill Country gravel experience without premium pricing.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $20. Reasonable total expenses with Austin-area access. Lodging options range from budget to mid-range in Georgetown and Austin. The short distance means minimal gear requirements and travel is straightforward from a major metro area. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

length.explanation: At 30 miles, this falls under the <40mi threshold. It's a manageable single-distance format that works well for both newcomers to gravel and experienced riders looking for a shorter effort. Shorter than Little Sugar MTB.

technicality.explanation: Texas Hill Country limestone gravel with some rough sections and technical elements, but nothing extreme. The terrain includes ranch roads and rolling hills without singletrack or highly technical descents. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: With 2,000+ feet of climbing over 30 miles, this averages out to steady but moderate climbing. The Texas Hill Country provides rolling terrain rather than sustained mountain climbs. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 66°F and lows of 48°F, with a 37% chance of rain on any given day. December in Texas Hill Country offers mild to cool temperatures (50s-60s°F), which is actually quite pleasant for racing. Occasional cold fronts possible but generally rider-friendly conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Texas Hill Country sits at relatively low elevation, well below 3,000 feet. No altitude acclimatization required - sea level performance applies. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

logistics.explanation: Walburg is located in the Austin metro area, requiring moderate travel planning. Austin-Bergstrom International Airport is nearby, and hotels are available in Georgetown and Austin, though Walburg itself is a small community.

adventure.explanation: The Texas Hill Country provides memorable ranch scenery, rolling limestone landscapes, and Texas gravel character. While not a bucket-list epic, it offers a distinctively Texan gravel experience with festive post-race atmosphere.

final_verdict.one_liner: A perfectly adequate 30-miler that exists without apology or ambition.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you need a low-stakes shakedown ride or you're testing new gear, the Walburg Dirty 30 delivers exactly what it promises—nothing more, nothing less. The 2000 feet of climbing won't break you, but it won't make you either. Show up if you want to ride bikes with people who also want to ride bikes, just don't expect stories worth telling afterward.
final_verdict.alternatives: The Dirty Kanza 100 in Kansas offers real suffering if you want to test yourself, while the Mid South in Oklahoma gives you legitimate bragging rights with better competition and nastier conditions.

course_description.character: Walburg Dirty 30 rolls through classic Texas hill country where limestone climbs bite harder than they look and exposed ridgelines offer zero mercy from the elements. The first half lulls you into thinking this is just another rolling gravel cruise before the back half delivers a masterclass in why elevation numbers lie.

suffering_zones.label: The False Promise
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling farm roads make you feel clever about your pacing strategy. Save the victory lap—you're burning matches you'll need later.

suffering_zones.label: Reality Check Ridge
suffering_zones.desc: The climbs start stacking and the limestone kicks up through worn gravel. Your legs remember this isn't a recovery ride anymore.

suffering_zones.label: The Reckoning
suffering_zones.desc: Exposed ridgeline climbing where the wind picks a direction just to mess with you. Whatever fitness you thought you had gets audited here.

course_description.signature_challenge: The final 5-mile stretch compounds every mistake you made earlier—loose limestone surfaces, punchy climbs, and zero shelter from whatever weather Texas decides to throw at you. Your legs are cooked, the rocks are loose, and the hills don't negotiate.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

primary.name: Goodyear Connector
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

primary.name: Continental Terra Trail
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
